There were
several
planes around.
I recognized a Junkers warming up and
a Beacheraf't and I saw the DO-two which the Ministry of Conmunicationa
Allison is flying it just now.
The Business Manager net me and told me he had made an appoint-
ment for me to see the Minister at ten that night.
I went over to the
U.S.S, Luzon and had dinner and stayed until nearly ten when I went around
to the hotel
to see the Minister.
The Bund all along where the Luson tied
up was crowded with Chinese soldiers but there was no semblance of order at
Many of then looked in
the dark like
convalescent wounded.
or armed troups nor mes there any disorderly conduet that I saw.
Only hopelesa confusion.
I saw the Minister and explained to him what the conditions wore
and told him the next night if possible, we would fly tao tripe each with
both DO-twoa from Hankow to Ichung which was safer for the passengers and
then one trip each plane to Chungking.
Also we would have two Commodores
out of Hankow for Ichang on the morning of the 25th.
Also the Commodores
would return to Hankow fron Ichang the evening of the 25th and sould
evacuate the CNAC staff on the morning of the 26th.
The Minister was very
much pleased, and said we were doing all that could be expected.
General
Chen, Head of
the Military Aviation was with the Minister and so was Ex-
Minister Chu Chis. Hua.
I then went around to see the Scaony people and got them out of
They said they expected to save all of our gas and eventually get it
to Chungking â€¢
They also promised to send our gas up to Chungking on the
first trip their steaner made which they thought would be soon, as soon
as the river got a little lower.
I then went around to CNAC office and outlined all the evacuation
procedure for the morning of the 26th.
ALso I asked our agent to give me all
the cash he had and I would take it back to Chungking with me.
He bad about
thirty three thousend dollars in his safe.
I took thirty thousand of
left him
the balance for energency.
I then went around to the Fienes Hotel
and got a room.
It was then one o'clock in the morning and I had to get up
at three and I was so keyed up I never slept at all.
got up at three and
went back to CNACis office where the passengers were assembling.
They were
there and they certainly were rearing to go.
field about four.
The road out was thronged with people on foot evacusting.
Everything was ready and we got off about five juat as it started to rain.
The trip back was also uneventful.
The weather was the same as coming down
only it had got a little colder and we picked up a little ice but not much.
I learned while in Fankow that our Connodore did not get to Henkow that
afternoon but remined in Ichang.
That upset me because every trip counted
and there was no reason for it not getting in.
On ay return to Chungking I had breakfast and then went to the
office
to work arranging the details for the flights that night and clearing
up some of the
things on ny desk. I also sent a message to the pilot on the
Connodore who had renined in Ichang, Hugh Chen,
telling him I would like
for him
to go on to lankow that afternoon, the 24th, and fly back to Ichane
with passengers on the 25th, then return to Hankow on the evening of the 25th,
